consistent certification criteria, promotes continuous improvement, and differentiates from related

3.0SCOPE

This policy applies to all RTD modalities.
3.1 Major Capital Projects

All major HA-funded capital projects must adhere to the SSCP as detailed in the FTA Handbook for Transit
Safety and Security Certification. Additionally, the FRA req uires all major railroad projects that extend,
rehabilitate, or modify an existing system or replace vehicles and equipment, as stipulated within 49 CFR
Part 270, must follow this policy as referenced within the System Safety Program Plan.
Notable major capita l projects demanding a comprehensive SSCP comprise:
•

Initiating new rail lines or existing rail line extensions of (e.g., W Line, R Line, L Line, N Line, etc.)

•

New bus fl eet and associated facilities

•

Significant infrast ructure repair

3.2 Modifications/ Rehabilitations

Certain projects might necessitate a scaled down version of the certification process proportional to risk.
Such projects are subject to Safety and Security certification based on their impact on existing operations.
The requisite certification level is determined by t he Manager of Safety Assurance and Certification based
on the hazard risk of the project as referenced in RTO's Operational Risk Management Framework.
The following are examples of projects that can be evaluated for a scaled down certification approach:

•
•
•
•
•

Partial rail replacements
OCS wire replacement
Highblock replacements
Bus stop relocations
Facilities retrofits

A Preliminary Hazard Analysis (provides an early assessment of the hazards associated with
a design or concept. The PHA identifies critical areas, hazards and criteria being used, and
considers hazardous components, interfaces, environmental constraints, as well as operating,
maintenance, and emergency procedures.
Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan
Means freedom from harm resulting from unintentional acts or circumstances
Means freedom from harm resulting from intentional acts or circumstances

SSCF

Safety and Security Certification Framework

SSCP

Safety and Security Certification Program ensures that all critical system elements have been
monitored for safety and security from development throughout implementation, and the
findings documented. The results will be documented by a series of certificates attesting to
conformance with safety and security requirements of the individual system elements,
procedures, and training programs. The program identifies functional responsibilities and
establishes a methodology to provide the necessary documentation to support the safety
certification process.
Safety Open Items List is a project management tool that records and tracks unresolved
safety and operational issues identified during the various certification phases of a project. It
serves as a cri tical mechanism for ongoing risk management, providing a structured
framework for documenting, prioritizing, and addressing safety and operational concerns that
arise after the initial implementation of the CEL and CIL. The SOIL ensures that all issues are
either resolved or evaluated for acceptable risk, thereby, enhancing compliance with safety
regulations and facilitating clear communication among stakeholders. This list is pivotal in
maintaining the integrity of the project's safety and operational standards, supporting the
overall certification process by ensuring that no critical safety issues are overlooked before
t he proiect tran sitions to its operational phase.
State Safety Oversight Agency, in RTD's case the SSOA is the Colorado Public Utilities
Commission.
System Safety and Security Working Group, which encompasses relevant stakeholders,
oversees and administers the SSCP and all the safety and security elements.
A Threat and Vulnerability Analysis provides an evaluation of a transit/rail system's
susceptibility to security threats and to identify vulnerabilities and potential consequences.
The assessment forms the basis for design measures, plans and procedures to be
implemented to reduce or mitigate the security risk

SSWG

6.0 SAFETY AND SECURITY CERTIFICATION PROCESS
Implementation of the policy will be scaled according to project scope, size, co mplexity, and risk. The
minimum requirements are the key steps outlined below and furthe r elaborated within the Safety and
Security Certification Framework.
The process involves:
•

Stakeholder Engagement: Identify relevant impacted stakeholders {internal and external} and

seek feedback for eva luation and risk mitigation
•

Design Verification : Adopting a risk-based safety and security design aligned with standa rds

•

Construction Verification: Ensuring adherence to the certified design, emphasizing safety and

security aspects
•

Integration Testing Verification: Evaluating the comprehensive syst em before operational

commencement
•

Pre-revenue Testing Verification: Ensuring system operates as designed and constructed prior to

placement in revenue service
•

Operation: Prioritizing safety and security during system operation

•

Review and Audit: Frequent ly assessing and modifying safety measures

INTRODUCTION
The State Safety Oversight (SSO) Program was created as part of the Intermodal Surface

Federal Transit Administration (FTA) in 49 Code of Federal Regulations (C.F.R.) Part 659 (Part
659) published in the Federal Register on December 27, 1995, and amended in the Federal
Register December 23, 1996. The Part 659 rules were updated again and published in the
Federal Register on April 29, 2005. The 2005 Part 659 rules outlined the requirements for state
safety and security oversight of Rail Fixed Guideway Systems (RFGS) within the state. Any
RFGS’s that: 1) did not fall under the jurisdiction of the Federal Railroad Administration (FRA);
2) were included in FTA’s calculation of fixed guideway route miles or were receiving funding
under FTA’s formula program for urbanized areas (49 U.S.C. 5336); or 3) had submitted
documentation to FTA indicating intent to be included in FTA’s calculation of fixed guideway
route miles or to receive funding under FTA’s formula program for urbanized areas (49 U.S.C.
5336) were subject to oversight pursuant to Part 659. If a state failed to implement a program
and designate an agency responsible for safety and security oversight of an RFGS operation, then
the state may have been subject to penalties. If a state had not met these requirements or made
adequate efforts to comply with them, then the secretary of the FTA could have withheld up to
five percent of a fiscal year’s apportionment under FTA’s formula program for urbanized areas
attributable to the state or an affected urbanized area in the state.
In 2012, Congress passed the Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st Century Act (MAP-

Attachment: PTASP_Exhibits_2026 (5203 : 2026 Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP))

Transportation Efficiency Act (ISTEA) of 1991 and implemented with rules promulgated by the

21), which went into effect on October 1, 2012, and is codified at 49 U.S.C. § 5329. The MAP21 legislation directed FTA to establish a comprehensive public transportation safety program
which included explicit statutory mandates to strengthen state oversight of the safety of Rail
iii
Packet Pg. 580

4.A.b

Transit Agencies (RTAs). Requirements of this new mandate include that state oversight
agencies have the necessary enforcement authority, legal, and financial independence from the

its jurisdiction. FTA enacted new SSO rules at 49 C.F.R. Part 674, which went into effect on
April 15, 2016. Pursuant to the requirements of the MAP-21 legislation, SSO Agencies have
three years from the date of enactment – until April 15, 2019 – to have their SSO programs
certified as being in compliance with the new Part 674 rules. The Commission’s program was
certified on April 6, 2018.
In 2021, Congress passed the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL), which went into effect
on November 15, 2021, and is codified at 49 U.S.C. §5329. The BIL legislation at 49 U.S.C. §
5329(k) requires SSO Agencies to develop and implement a risk-based inspection program. The
BIL also directed FTA to issue a Special Directive to each SSOA on the development and
implementation of a risk-based inspection program per 49 U.S.C. § 5329(k)(5). Special
Directive 22-26 was issued to the Commission on October 21, 2022. The Commission must first
submit documentation that demonstrates the Commission has developed a risk-based inspection
program within two years of the Special Directive, or by October 21, 2024. FTA must approve
the new program. Second, the Commission must, within one year after FTA’s approval of the
risk-based inspection program, submit documentation that demonstrates that the Commission has
implemented that approved program for at least six months. The Commission submitted its
risk-based inspection program on June 14, 2024. The risk-based inspection program was
approved by FTA on June 26, 2025.

RTAs, and human resources for overseeing the number, size, and complexity of the RTAs within

The Commission conducts its business using the Rules of Practice and Procedure found
at 4 Code of Colorado Regulations 723-1. These Rules are promulgated by the Commission
through a rulemaking process and are subject to review by the Colorado Attorney General’s
Office before becoming effective. In the absence of a specific rule to govern a situation, the
Commission’s Rules of Practice and Procedure govern. These rules also govern the actions of
the Commission and its staff in their dealings with the public and the entities that it oversees and
regulates.
The State Safety Oversight Program Standard for Rail Fixed Guideway Public
Transportation Systems (Program Standard) is codified within the Commission rules that govern
the oversight of RTAs. The specific rules pertaining to the safety oversight of RFGSs are found
in 4 CCR 723-7-7340 through 7355 (Rules 7340 through 7363). These rules can be changed
only through a formal rulemaking process.
The SSO Program Manager is responsible for the overall application and use of these
procedures. These procedures of the SSO Program are developed by SSOA Staff, under
authority granted by the Commission found at Rule 7343(a)(IX) as an internal procedural guide
for conducting activities necessary to meet the requirements of the Program Standard.
The SSO activities described in these procedures are intentionally meant to be flexible so that
they may be easily modified to fit current circumstances within the scope of the work performed

Attachment: PTASP_Exhibits_2026 (5203 : 2026 Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP))

Department of Labor and Employment, Division of Oil and Public Safety.

by an RTA and so they are commensurate with the complexity of each RTA overseen. During
initial construction, or periods of extensive modifications or extensions, there will naturally be
v
Packet Pg. 582

4.A.b

additional emphasis on safety oversight of design and construction activities in addition to the
revenue service safety oversight activities.

inspection audit programs, nor shall they relieve the RTA in any way of its total responsibility
for the safety of its operations. The Commission’s SSO activities are intended to supplement
those of the RTA and provide an added degree of confidence that the safety policies and
procedures described in the RTA’s Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP) and
Roadway Worker Protection (RWP) program are being successfully carried out in actual
practice.
These procedures serve as the instrument for documenting any safety concerns that
SSOA Staff may have regarding RTA operations, are risk-based inspections, and ongoing
inspections. These processes and procedures are developed in consultation with each RTA
overseen by the Commission.
Until August 6, 2025, all procedures involving investigation reports and corrective action
plans prepared by an RTA and filed with the Commission were to be treated by the Commission
and its SSOA Staff as confidential under applicable law, including the Colorado Open Records
Act, § 24-72-201 to 206, C.R.S.; §40-18-104, C.R.S.; and Rule 7349(c)(IV). On August 6, 2025,
Senate Bill 25-052 became effective statutorily changing the confidentiality of Commission
reports. Under the new statute and temporary Commission rule, an investigation of the
Commission may remain confidential while the investigation is ongoing. Once the report is
adopted as a final report of the Commission, the final report will be available to the public with

SOP-101

1.0
SCOPE
This procedure describes the SSOA Staff requirements to annually review the Program Standard
and Procedures Manual.
2.0
PURPOSE
The purpose of this procedure is to outline the SSOA Staff process for annually reviewing the
Program Standard and Procedures Manual.
3.0

4.0

PROGRAM STANDARD REVIEW PROCEDURE
3.1
No later than December 31st of each year, SSOA Staff shall review the Program
Standard to determine if any changes are necessary. SSOA Staff will work with
the affected RTA to receive input in determining if changes are necessary.
Changes to the Program Standard will likely be the result of any FTA rule
changes that affect the Program Standard.
3.2

SSOA Staff will report to the Commission and provide a memorandum
summarizing SSOA Staff’s review of the Program Standard and will state
whether changes are required to the Program Standard.

3.3

If changes to the Program Standard are necessary, SSOA Staff will assist the
Commission in preparing the required rulemaking and will inform the RTA about
the forthcoming rulemaking so they may participate in the rulemaking process.
Once the rulemaking is complete, the revised rule will be published in the
Colorado Register and the rules will be updated on the Commission’s website.
The RTA will be informed when the revised rules are available on the
Commission’s website.

3.4

Any Program Standard changes will be provided to FTA as part of the
Commission’s annual report to the FTA.

PROCEDURES MANUAL REVIEW PROCEDURE
4.1
No later than January 1st of each year, SSOA Staff shall review the Procedures
Manual to determine if any changes are necessary. SSOA Staff will work with
the affected RTA to receive input in determining if changes are necessary.
Changes to the Procedures Manual will likely be the result of any data storage
process changes, rule changes, or standard operating procedure changes at the
RTA, or changes resulting from an FTA rulemaking.
4.2

Attachment: PTASP_Exhibits_2026 (5203 : 2026 Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP))

PROCEDURE FOR ANNUAL PROGRAM STANDARD AND
PROCEDURES MANUAL REVIEW

If changes to the Procedures Manual are necessary, SSOA Staff will work with
the affected RTA on those procedure changes. Once the Procedures Manual is

Commission’s annual report to the FTA. If changes are made outside of the
annual reporting period, the SSOA will upload the new Procedures Manual into
the SSOR system.

SOP-102

1.0
SCOPE
This procedure describes the Commission dispute resolution process that will be used to mediate
issues between SSOA Staff and the RTA during the CAP review and approval process.
2.0
PURPOSE
The purpose of this procedure is to outline the dispute resolution process that will be used to
mediate any issues between SSOA Staff and the RTA during the CAP review and approval
process.
3.0

DISPUTE RESOLUTION PROCESS
3.1
Mediation will be used as the Commission’s dispute resolution process. This
process provides the following advantages over directly moving to a formal
complaint procedure:
●
User Friendly – mediation is an informal process
●
Saves Time – disputes can usually be resolved in a few hours
●
Saves Money – the mediation process is free to both parties and saves the
cost of a formal complaint hearing
●
Flexibility – mediation creates an opportunity for a wider range of
solutions and possible options to resolve the dispute
●
Private – only the mediator and parties, and their representatives may be
present
●
Preservation of Good Will – mediation preserves goodwill because it
fosters communication and the continuation of a good business
relationship
●
Confidential – information discussed may not be used as evidence in any
formal complaint proceeding or other judicial proceeding
●
Qualified Mediators – mediation uses PUC employees trained in
mediation to facilitate discussion
●
Results – the mediation process is expected to result in an outcome where
everyone feels they have achieved their desired goals
3.2

Once a CAP issue that requires the Commission’s dispute resolution process
occurs, a “Request for Mediation Form” will be provided to SSOA Staff and the
RTA. Each party will provide the information requested on the form and provide
the completed form to the attention of the PUC Mediation Coordinator within five
business days of receiving the form. Both parties must agree to the mediation
process.

Attachment: PTASP_Exhibits_2026 (5203 : 2026 Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP))

PROCEDURE FOR DISPUTE RESOLUTION BETWEEN SSOA
STAFF AND THE RTA

4
Packet Pg. 590

3.3

If both parties agree to mediate, the PUC will assign a mediator who does not
have any financial or personal interest in the result of the mediation. At the
mediator’s discretion, both parties may be asked to produce all necessary
information for the mediator to understand the issue. At the initial mediation
session, both parties will be asked to sign a “Mediation Conditions Agreement.”

3.4

During the mediation session, the mediator may conduct joint and separate
meetings with the parties. No conclusions should be drawn based on the time the
mediator spends with either party. The mediator may be trying to explain the
other party’s position or may be helping the other party evaluate positions in a
different light. The mediator will work with both parties to assist in creating a
settlement to resolve the CAP dispute. A settlement agreement cannot be forced
or required by either party. The mediator does not have the authority to impose a
settlement and cannot offer legal advice. The mediator may end the mediation
when, in his/her judgment, further efforts will not resolve the dispute.

3.5

If the dispute is resolved during the session, the mediator will draft a settlement
agreement to be signed by both parties and will assist in drafting language to
change the CAP to conform to the settlement agreement, and the CAP will be
submitted to the Commission for review and approval.

3.6

The content of all mediation sessions and settlements is confidential and is not to
be disclosed to any other party and is not precedent-setting. If a settlement is not
reached, views or suggestions made in mediation cannot be introduced as
evidence during any formal proceedings. There will not be any recorded or
stenographic record of the mediation.

3.7

If either party chooses not to mediate, the CAP issue will move forward through
the formal complaint process.

PROCEDURE FOR SCHEDULING INSPECTIONS
WITH ADVANCED NOTICE AND WITHOUT ADVANCED
NOTICE
1.0

SCOPE

This procedure describes scheduling inspections with advanced notice and without advanced
notice of light rail facilities, inspection reports, infrastructure, practices specific to the RTA,
event verification, equipment inspection, data, ongoing monitoring, record inspections, and
personnel on the RTA properties performed by SSOA Staff.
2.0

PURPOSE

The purpose of this procedure is to provide a general guideline to be used by SSOA Staff when
scheduling inspections with advanced notice and without advanced notice of light rail facilities,
inspection reports, infrastructure, practices specific to the RTA, event verification, equipment
inspection, data, ongoing monitoring, record inspections, and personnel on the RTA properties
performed by SSOA Staff.
3.0

4.0

GENERAL INSPECTION INFORMATION
3.1

The RTA will provide every month with a schedule of upcoming construction
projects to the SSOA Staff to allow the SSOA Staff to conduct inspections with
advanced notice and without advanced notice. Schedules will be provided during
the monthly RTA SSOA meeting.

3.2

The RTA will provide access to SSOA Staff for access with and without
advanced notice. Access will be dependent on the necessary safety training and
requirements to safely access facilities, including, but not limited to, on-track
safety training, use of personal protective equipment, facility awareness, lock out
tag out training, and accompaniment of an RTA employee with appropriate
communication devices. The RTA will provide all necessary training.

3.3

The SSOA Program manager will schedule all with advanced notice inspections
with the RTA's safety team or appropriate management team, the RTA's Chief
Safety Officer, or the assigned escort will be notified prior to or upon arrival of
the SSOA Staff.

ACCESS PROCEDURES AND ESCORTS
4.1
SSOA Staff will provide notice to the RTA 24 hours in advance of the day, time,
and location SSOA Staff will need to gain access to the RTA facilities.
4.2
Escorts will be at the discretion of the RTA, depending on what type of inspection
is being performed. Public areas such as trains and stations will not need an escort
for access for the SSOA Staff to perform inspections.

Attachment: PTASP_Exhibits_2026 (5203 : 2026 Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP))

SOP-103

6
Packet Pg. 592

4.A.b

4.4
4.5
5.0

6.0

SSOA Staff must report to the scheduled location where the inspection is being
performed.
SSOA Staff will meet with RTA representatives and attend any job safety
briefings prior to performing any inspections.
RTA representatives will verify certifications and training of the SSOA Staff to
ensure their compliance with the RTA safety protocols and requirements.

INSPECTIONS WITH ADVANCED NOTICE
5.1

On the internal SSOA Staff shared calendar, the SSOA Staff will enter the time
and date that the SSOA Staff member plans to perform the inspection. Use the
title Field inspection without advanced notice or with advanced notice.

5.2

All inspections with advanced notice will be scheduled at least 24 hours before
an inspection.

5.3

SSOA Staff will be required to have current and up-to-date RTA-provided ontrack training and LRFSA training prior to gaining access to the RTA’s
properties.

5.4

All inspections with advanced notice will be done by contacting the facility
Supervisor or a member of Safety by phone or email to schedule the inspection
with the date, time, and the SSOA Staff member(s) name performing the
inspection with the RTA. The RTA will be notified of what type of inspection
will be performed.

5.5

When conducting a facility inspection with advanced notice, the on-duty
supervisor will be notified prior to any work being conducted. The RTA
supervisor will be notified of what type of inspection is being conducted and
what time the SSOA Staff plans to start and end the facility inspection. The RTA
supervisor will verify that the SSOA Staff have completed the proper training,
and that the training is current for the SSOA Staff member. When the inspection
is done, the RTA supervisor will be notified that the inspection is done.

INSPECTION WITHOUT ADVANCED NOTICE
6.1

The SSOA Staff employees should enter the time and date the employee plans to
perform the inspection on the internal SSOA Staff shared calendar. Use the title
Field Inspection Without Advanced Notice.

6.2

The SSOA Staff will notify the RTA of the date and time of the unannounced
inspection in advance to ensure there is an appropriate RTA staff to accompany
the SSOA Staff. The SSOA Staff will not reveal the type or location of the
inspection at that time.

6.3

The SSOA Staff will notify the RTA of the location of the inspection at least one
hour prior to arriving to coordinate with the RTA.

6.4

Once the SSOA Staff arrive, the SSOA Staff will notify the proper supervisor or
staff member at the facility. The RTA representative will escort the SSOA Staff
during the inspection.

PROCEDURE FOR SUBMITTAL, REVIEW, AND
COMMISSION APPROVAL OF THE PUBLIC
TRANSPORTATION AGENCY SAFETY PLAN (PTASP)
1.0
SCOPE
This procedure describes the SSOA Staff activities and process of submitting, reviewing, and
approving the PTASP prepared and submitted by RTAs.
2.0
PURPOSE
The purpose of this procedure is to provide a general guideline to be used by SSOA Staff for
the process of reviewing and recommending for approval the PTASP submitted by RTAs.
3.0

PROCEDURE
3.1

No later than November 1st of each year, the RTA shall submit its PTASP to the
Commission for review and approval.

3.2

SSOA Staff shall review the PTASP using the “Checklist for PTASP Review”
(See Form in Appendix I).

3.3

No later than December 20th of each year, SSOA Staff shall notify the RTA in
writing of any deficiencies found in its review in accordance with Rules 1303(c)
and 7346(c). The RTA shall be required to submit a revised PTASP correcting all
deficiencies noted.

3.4

If the RTA fails to make the revisions necessary to correct the deficiencies
identified by SSOA Staff, the matter will be submitted to the Commission for
determination pursuant to Rules 1303(c) and 7346(c).

3.5

Once all deficiencies have been corrected, or if no deficiencies were found in the
PTASP review, SSOA Staff will submit the completed “Checklist for PTASP
Review” to the Commission, and the Commission shall issue a decision formally
approving the RTA’s PTASP. A copy of the completed checklist used to review
and verify PTASP compliance will be included with the order.

PROCEDURE FOR REVIEW OF RTA’S
SAFETY EVENT INVESTIGATIONS AND REPORTING, AND
COMMISSION ADOPTION OF SAFETY EVENT REPORTS
1.0
SCOPE
This procedure describes the activities of SSOA Staff for safety oversight of RTA safety event
investigations and reporting.
2.0
PURPOSE
The purpose of this procedure is to establish a standard set of instructions for SSOA Staff to
follow in the safety oversight of investigation and reporting of safety events.
3.0

4.0

ASSIGNMENT OF TRACKING NUMBERS
3.1
The following format will be used as a means for the assignment of a tracking
number to safety events.
3.2

All safety events shall be assigned a tracking number at the time of their reporting
or discovery. The tracking number will be a ten-digit alphanumeric number.

3.3

The first character of the tracking number will be an A to signify that it is an
safety event that is required to be reported to the Commission.

3.4

The second character of the tracking number is a number detailing the
chronological order of the safety event to occur on that day. For example: the
second safety event in a single day would be noted as A2-xxxxxxxx and the first
as A1-xxxxxxxx.

3.5

The next eight digits, preceded by a hyphen, define the date for the safety event
starting with month (two digits), day (two digits), and year (four digits). For
example, A1-08222017 would be the first reportable accident to occur on August
22, 2017.

SAFETY EVENT INVESTIGATION GUIDELINES
5.1

Each RTA shall investigate safety events on behalf of SSOA Staff.

5.2

All safety event meetings and the notification thresholds identified in 4.1 above
shall be investigated.

5.3

The RTA shall give prior sufficient telephone notice to SSOA Staff of the times
that a safety event investigation team will conduct interviews, inspections,
examinations, or tests to determine the cause of the safety event. SSOA Staff will
oversee an RTA’s internal investigation through participation in the RTA’s safety
event investigation team activities, as necessary, and through monthly
investigation review meetings.

5.4

SSOA Staff shall review the applicable reports, records, transcripts, meeting
minutes, etc., for any investigation activity not participated in directly by SSOA
Staff.

5.5

To the extent that they are applicable and pertinent to the safety event under
investigation, SSOA Staff may review:

Vehicle, track, switch, and signal maintenance records

Test procedures and recorded results of operational reenactments
Historical reports of earlier similar accident or hazard occurrences

4.A.b

SAFETY EVENT RESULTING IN NTSB INVESTIGATION
7.1

In the event of an NTSB investigation of an RFGPTS safety event, the
Commission shall cooperate fully with the NTSB investigation team, including
participation in the NTSB party system. The Commission reserves the right to
contact the NTSB, independent of the RTA, to discuss all matters related to the
investigation.

7.2

In the event of an NTSB investigation, the Commission shall participate in any
investigation conducted or findings and recommendations made by the NTSB.

7.3

The Commission will evaluate the findings from any NTSB accident investigation
and will determine if a CAP should be developed by either the Commission or
RTA to address the NTSB findings.

8.0
QUARTERLY COMMISSION SAFETY EVENT REPORT REVIEW AND
ADOPTION
8.1

SSOA Staff will prepare a summary report of all accident reports for safety events
that have occurred during each of the four quarters of the year (Q1 = January
through March, Q2=April through June, Q3=July through September, and Q4=
October through December).

8.2

Each quarterly report will provide a summary of the safety event that occurred, a
list of all the safety events including date, time, location, brief summary, type of
safety events, and any citations issued, and a five-year quarter over quarter safety
events trend analysis.

8.3

SSOA Staff will analyze event trends over a 5-year period, quarterly. Each
quarterly report will have a summary of the areas that have similar event types
and the location of high-frequency events.

8.4

Event types will be tracked with an ongoing monitoring tracker to watch trends in
event types and event locations.

PROCEDURE FOR REVIEW, PRELIMINARY APPROVAL,
TRACKING OF CAPs, AND QUARTERLY REPORTING OF
CAPs TO THE COMMISSION FOR APPROVAL
1.0
SCOPE
This procedure describes the activities of SSOA Staff for the review, preliminary approval of
CAPs for any CAP that is not the result of a hazard that meets a risk assessment code of 1A, 2A,
1B, 2B, or 1C, and tracking of all CAPs. This procedure also describes the activities of SSOA
Staff in preparing the quarterly reporting of CAPs to the Commission for approval.
2.0
PURPOSE
The purpose of this procedure is to establish guidelines for SSOA Staff review and preliminary
approval of CAPs, tracking of all CAPs, and preparation of the quarterly reporting to the
Commission for Commission CAP approval.
3.0

GENERAL REQUIREMENTS
3.1
The RTA is responsible for developing a CAP for:
●
Results from investigations in which the RTA or SSOA Staff identifies
causal and contributing factors that require corrective action(s)
●
Hazard findings from safety reviews performed by SSOA Staff or RTA
internal safety reviews
●
Any safety condition reported through the RTA-established safety
condition reporting process
3.2

The RTA shall assign tracking numbers to each CAP and shall maintain a
computerized log for the tracking and recordkeeping of CAPs. SSOA Staff shall
use this computerized log to review, preliminarily approve, and actively monitor
the progress, log final Commission approval, and close-out of each CAP. SSOA
Staff shall meet or communicate periodically with the RTA during the entire CAP
process.

3.3

All correspondence between the RTA and SSOA Staff concerning CAPs will
include the CAP tracking number. Examples of application and use of the
tracking control number include:
●
On quarterly CAP status reports
●
On quarterly Commission CAP approval summary reports
●
On the cover page of a safety event or hazard report
●
On any correspondence pertaining to a CAP

Attachment: PTASP_Exhibits_2026 (5203 : 2026 Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP))

QUARTERLY COMMISSION CAP REVIEW AND APPROVAL
REQUIREMENTS
4.1

SSOA Staff will prepare a summary report of all CAPs that have occurred during
each of the four quarters of the year (Q1 = January through March, Q2 = April
through June, Q3 = July through September, and Q4 = October through
December).

4.2

Each quarterly report will provide a list of all of the CAPs opened during the
quarter, the status of the CAP, and a summary and analysis of the types of CAPs
that occurred during the quarter. For any CAPs that were not closed during
previous quarters, the report will also include the CAPs that were open from
previous quarters and the date on which the CAP was closed.

Open the ‘CAP Tracking List’ tab

Scroll down to the bottom of the worksheet

Input the new CAP information on a new row

(viii)

Determine if CAP is appropriate. If not, set up an additional meeting with RTA
to discuss CAP.

Fill out and email the Preliminary Approval form to the RTA

(x)

Save a copy of the Preliminary Approval form in the folder with the CAP

(xi)

Quarterly review of any outstanding CAPs for potential closure with the RTA

(xii)

Submit Quarterly CAP Report to the Commission

(xiii)

Document CAP closures on the HA & CAP Tracking Log, or the CAP Tracking
log.

PROCEDURE FOR REVIEW AND APPROVAL OF RTA’s
CORRECTIVE ACTION PLANS

21
Packet Pg. 607

4.A.b

SOP-403

1.0
SCOPE
This procedure describes the activities for SSOA Staff to verify the completion of an RTA CAP
and to recommend CAP closure to the Commission.
2.0
PURPOSE
The purpose of this procedure is to establish guidelines for SSOA Staff to verify the completion
of a CAP by the RTA and to recommend closure of the CAP to the Commission.
3.0

GENERAL REQUIREMENTS
3.1
The RTA will inform SSOA Staff when there are CAPs ready to be reviewed for
completion and closure. The RTA can inform SSOA Staff if there are parts of a
CAP ready to be reviewed and verified for closure.
3.2

SSOA Staff are responsible for reviewing all documentation and verifying any
on-site changes required to meet the requirements outlined in CAP.

3.3

SSOA Staff and the RTA will work together to schedule time either virtually
and/or in person to provide the documentation for review and verification of any
on-site changes made to address the CAP.

3.4

The RTA is responsible for having all documentation available for SSOA Staff
review that documents the requirements of the CAP item have been
completed. The RTA is also responsible for arranging for SSOA Staff on-site
verification of implementation, if required, for any items that are part of the
Commission-approved CAP.

3.5

To assess if CAPs have been implemented effectively and have addressed the
safety concerns identified to mitigate the safety risk, after being verified for
completeness and approval, SSOA Staff will continue ongoing monitoring to
verify the CAP continues to meet its original requirements. SSOA Staff will
continue ongoing monitoring of closed CAPs biannually and annually to ensure
CAPs are still effective, and verify the RTA is still implementing CAP items as
approved by the Commission. This progress will be tracked through a
spreadsheet. Ongoing monitoring will be done through a monthly data
reconciliation meeting with the RTA, onsite inspections, and/or documentation
requests to verify things are being done according to the CAP.

3.6

At the monthly Safety meeting between RTA and SSOA Staff, Open CAPs are
discussed to track CAP completion progress.

Attachment: PTASP_Exhibits_2026 (5203 : 2026 Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP))

PROCEDURE FOR CAP COMPLETION VERIFICATION AND
CAP CLOSURE RECOMMENDATION TO THE COMMISSION

22
Packet Pg. 608

3.7

At the CAP verification meeting, the RTA and SSOA Staff will review all CAPs
with a status of OPEN and discuss the measures taken thus far towards closure,
and SSOA Staff will determine from this information if any on-site meetings need
to be scheduled for clarification

3.8

Once SSOA Staff have reviewed all documentation and reviewed any on-site
changes, SSOA Staff shall document the SSOA Staff implementation verification
date on the CAP tracker.

4.0
QUARTERLY COMMISSION CAP CLOSURE
SSOA Staff will prepare a summary report of all CAPs that have occurred during each of the
four quarters of the year (Q1 = January through March, Q2 = April through June, Q3 = July
through September, and Q4 = October through December), including all outstanding open CAPs.

AUDIT SOPs – SECTION 600

29

Packet Pg. 615

4.A.b

SOP-601

1.0

SCOPE
1.1
This procedure describes the activities of SSOA Staff for performing three-year
audits of RTA PTASP.
1.2

Each audit performed under this procedure is to be part of a series of semi-annual
on-site audits of the RTA. Due to the magnitude of performing a complete threeyear audit, the Commission has chosen to have SSOA Staff conduct six semiannual safety audits over the course of the three-year review process. The first
five semi-annual audits shall involve a review of approximately five to ten areas
of interest such that the entire PTASP is fully examined during the first five semiannual audits. The sixth semi-annual shall be comprised of a review of the
auditing process, procedures, and checklists used during the previous five semiannual audits to prepare checklists to be used for the next three-year review
process.

1.3

Semi-annual audits will generally be conducted at the RTA at approximately sixmonth intervals during the spring and fall of each year.

2.0 PURPOSE
The purpose of this procedure is to provide a general guideline to be used by the SSOA Staff in
performing the semi-annual audits of an RTA for purposes of evaluating if the RTA is in
compliance with its PTASP and to evaluate the overall effectiveness of the PTASP.
3.0

PRE-AUDIT PROCEDURE
3.1
Prior to notifying the RTA about an upcoming semi-annual audit, SSOA Staff
will review the checklists previously approved by the Commission that are
proposed to be audited to update the checklists for any changes that may have
occurred in the required documentation review. Documents that may be reviewed
prior to the on-site semi-annual audit include:
●
The RTA’s PTASP
●
The RTA’s operating rule book, bulletins, and standard operating
procedures
●
The RTA’s maintenance manuals and procedures for vehicles, track, and
signals
●
The RTA’s operator and mechanic training programs
●

3.3

SSOA Staff will notify the RTA at least 30 days prior to the start of the semiannual safety audit and will provide copies of the checklists to be audited. SSOA
Staff will work with the Safety Department Staff of the RTA to identify the
individuals to be contacted and scheduled for interview during the audit, identify
any records to be reviewed, and schedule any necessary field reviews, inspections,
and/or observations that are needed to complete the audit checklist. If requested
by the RTA, a meeting can be scheduled to assist in the discussion and scheduling
for each audit checklist.

4.0
OPTIONAL PRE-AUDIT MEETING
The RTA may request a pre-audit meeting to be held at least one week prior to the planned start
of the on-site auditing. RTA management and individuals identified to be part of the audit
should be in attendance if this meeting occurs. RTA personnel will have had a chance to look
over the audit checklists and may ask questions regarding the on-site audit to discuss and clarify
any materials, documentation, field checks, observations, and inspections that are proposed as
part of the audit. The audit sessions may also be scheduled during this meeting.
The following is a suggested agenda for the pre-audit meeting, if it occurs:
1.
Introduction and purpose
2.
Checklist review and modification
3.
Scheduling of audit sessions
4.
Required material and records
5.
Question and answer period
6.
Adjournment.
5.0

ON-SITE AUDIT
5.1
SSOA Staff will review all referenced documents prior to the on-site audit and
will review any requested documents that can be provided to SSOA Staff prior to
the start of the on-site audit to verify that the correct information was provided
and to ensure the documents are relevant to the scope of the checklists being
audited.

The on-site audit will be conducted as scheduled using the checklists provided to
the RTA. Each audit checklist element will be discussed and verified by
performing one or more of the following activities:
●
●
●
●
●

Interviews with RTA personnel
Review of RTA rules, procedures, and associated records responsive to the
checklist
Observation of operations and maintenance activities
Field reviews to verify information contained in records
Visual inspections and measurements

The audit checklists will identify minimum methods of verification. Minimum
verification methods shall not restrict SSOA Staff from performing additional
examinations and investigations when initial reviews appear to warrant further
inquiry to verify compliance with the RTA PTASP, operating rules, bulletins, and
standard operating procedures. Additional documents that are needed for
verification should be requested during interviews, observations, field reviews
and inspections. Requested documents should be provided to SSOA Staff during
the audit or within one week of the completion of the on-site audit sessions.
At all times, SSOA Staff must:
●
●
●
●
●

Perform a fact-based, verified audit which focuses on PTASP, rules,
procedures, programs and other regulatory guidelines compliance
Identify areas for recommended PTASP safety implementation
improvements
Operate without personal bias or personal interest, and without placing or
identifying blame
Use open-ended questions and interview techniques to elicit discussion of
safety programs, attitudes and practices
Provide support and oversight for corrective actions and safety program
development

Preliminary findings of non-compliance and recommendations noted during the
audit will be discussed with RTA personnel during the interview setting, or a
follow-up meeting will be scheduled to discuss any findings of non-compliance
and recommendations resulting from field reviews, observations, and inspections
prior to the formal audit report write-up. The RTA will be provided an
opportunity to comment and provide any additional information they may have
that could affect the audit checklist results and findings and/or recommendations.
6.0
OPTIONAL POST-AUDIT MEETING
The RTA may request a post-audit meeting to ask questions regarding the on-site audit to discuss
and clarify findings of non-compliance and recommendations made by SSOA Staff during the
on-site audit, and to discuss possible corrective actions. The post-audit meeting, if needed,
should be scheduled as soon as possible after the conclusion of the on-site audit.

DRAFT AUDIT REPORT
7.1
SSOA Staff will prepare a Draft Audit Report with completed audit checklists,
any audit findings or non-compliance and an evaluation of the effectiveness of the
RTA’s PTASP and whether the PTASP should be revised or updated. The
evaluation will be limited to the items that were examined or discovered during
the audit process. SSOA Staff may provide recommendations of changes or
revisions needed to the PTASP and may propose a schedule for when those
changes should occur.
7.2

SSOA Staff will provide a copy of its Draft Audit Report to the RTA for a 30-day
review and comment period.

7.3

The RTA is allowed to make corrections to any findings of non-compliance
and/or recommendations within the 30-day review period per Rule 7352(c).

7.4

The RTA may request a meeting with SSOA Staff during the RTA’s 30-day
review period to discuss the results of the audit checklist write-ups, and any
findings of non-compliance and/or recommendations.

7.5

The RTA will provide written comments and any proposed CAP’s and CAP
implementation schedules within 30 days of its receipt of the Draft Audit Report.

Attachment: PTASP_Exhibits_2026 (5203 : 2026 Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP))

4.A.b

FINAL AUDIT REPORT
33
Packet Pg. 619

8.1

SSOA Staff will prepare a Final Audit Report after the RTA’s comments have
been received with draft CAPs and implementation schedules. The Final Audit
Report will contain the completed audit checklists, RTA responses, any findings
of non-compliance, an evaluation of the effectiveness of the RTA’s PTASP and
whether the PTASP should be revised or updated, SSOA Staff recommendations
to the Commission regarding the proposed schedule for PTASP changes, if
necessary, and will include copies of the RTA’s draft CAP’s and implementation
schedules.

8.2

SSOA Staff shall file a copy of the Final Audit Report for each semi-annual audit
with the Commission for Commission review and approval.

8.3

If the RTA does not agree with the Final Audit Report filed by SSOA Staff, the
RTA will be required to intervene in the proceedings and request a hearing on the
matter.

8.4

All Final Audit Reports shall be approved by Commission order.

8.5

Once the Commission has approved the Final Audit Report, the attached CAPs
will be reviewed and approved pursuant to the requirements of Rule 7347(d)
depending on the risk assessment code and added to the RTA CAP tracking
matrix.

POLICIES AND PROCEDURE FOR MANAGEMENT AND
MAINTENANCE OF RTA DATA
1.0

SCOPE

This procedure describes the management of data regarding all data collected and analyzed from
the RTA Light Rail Operations, Maintenance, and Safety activities.
2.0

PURPOSE

The purpose of this procedure is to provide information regarding how data relating to the
RTA’s Light Rail Operations, Maintenance, and Safety activities are managed and maintained.
3.0

PROCEDURE
3.1

All data such as safety events, non-safety event, hazard, non-hazard, corrective
action plans, red signal violations, and other information received and generated
relating to the RTA Light Rail Operations, Maintenance, and Safety activities are
tracked using an Excel spreadsheet, filed electronically, and stored in Google
Drive under the PUC Rail & Transit folder.

3.2

The data received are analyzed, and reports are generated.

3.3

The data are filed under the RTA’s folder and organized and sorted according to
the data type and the year of occurrence.

3.4

All data is kept in Google Drive for at least 5 years.

3.5

Data stored for over 5 years is deleted from Google Drive by moving the file to a
trash bin. The trash folder is automatically emptied every 30 days.

3.6

The data system is maintained daily. All data that comes in electronically is
labeled, logged into the tracking spreadsheets, and electronically filed. All data is
filed in the original format to ensure the accuracy of all data stored.

3.7

All data, books, records, and documents collected by the SSOA are collected
under the Commission’s audit power pursuant to §§ 40-3-102; 40-3-110; 40-6106 and 40-6-107, C.R.S. generally, and shall be given confidential treatment
consistent with § 40-15-107(2)(a), C.R.S.

SCOPE

2.0

The purpose of this procedure is to provide information regarding the frequency of the data

3.0

PROCEDURE

The SSOA Staff will meet with the RTA monthly, quarterly, or annually to collect data from the
RTA based on the Risk-Based Inspection Frequency and Safety Metrics Mafrix. Some data will
be sent per occunence, monthly, quarterly, biannually, or annually by the RTA to the SSOA
Staff. The Risk-Based Inspection Frequency and Safety Metrics Matrix will be analyzed
ammally to verify if the collection frequency is still appropriate based on risk ranking
assessment. Meetings will be set up between the RTA and SSOA Staff to discuss
documentation once received and reviewed. The Risk-Based Inspection Frequency and Safety
Metrics Matrix shows the frequency of when data is collected and for which risk assessment
categories the data is collected to analyze. The Risk Assessment Matrix is found in SOP -704 Data Review, Data Analysis & Inspection Prioritization Process.

generally, and shall be given confidential treatment consistent with § 40-15-107(2)(a), C.R.S.

4.A.b

1.0

SCOPE

This procedure describes how collected data will be analyzed, and how inspections will be
prioritized based on their risk assessment ranking.
2.0

PURPOSE

The purpose of this procedure is to provide information on how often data is analyzed, and how
inspections are prioritized based on the risk assessment ranking from the data analysis.
3.0

PROCEDURE

The SSOA Staff will analyze data as outlined in the Risk-Based Inspection Frequency Matrix
contained in SOP 703.
SSOA Staff will compare and analyze data based on the frequency at which it is collected as
shown in the analysis for inspection & prioritization interval table below.
Risk scores/ratings are evaluated and calculated using the definitions for the severity category
and probability level to determine the risk level. Once risks are determined for each data
category, inspections will be prioritized based on the risk ranking for each type of data.
Data from the RTA and SSOA Staff inspections and other data (e.g., vehicle repair data, MOW
data, etc.) will be analyzed using Excel spreadsheets and graphs to show the risk ranking for all
the data for each specific type of data. The risk assessment, based on the risk ranking for each
specific data type, will be determined for and used in the ranking of inspection priorities.
SSOA Staff will work with each RTA to evaluate annually if there is a need to increase or
decrease the frequency of when data is collected based on their analysis of the data.
Data will be based on data collected from scheduled inspections, inspection reports, immediate
safety risks reported, inspections of equipment, inspections of infrastructure, or practices
specific to the RTA, event verification, ongoing monitoring, defects and corrective remedial
action, CAP, and safety mitigation verification.
Inspections are prioritized based on relevant data collected from the SSOA Staff and the
RTA. This includes safety program, maintenance, and inspection data collected by SSOA
Staff.

SOP 801
POLICY AND PROCEDURES FOR
FIELD FORMS AND INSPECTION REPORTS

46
Packet Pg. 632

4.A.b

20.

5.0

INSPECTION REPORT
●

All inspection reports will use objective language and objective data.

●

Once the Field Work form has been completed for an inspection, an inspection
report in Portable Document Format (PDF) format will be automatically
generated and emailed to the SSOA Staff and RTA within an hour.

●

The automatically generated email will have the sender’s information -- name, job
title, and email address. The sender is the SSOA Staff who performed the
inspection. Any additional information regarding the inspection will be issued by
the SSOA Staff who performed the inspection or any of the SSOA Staff.

●

An inspection report is generated for each type of inspection performed.

●

The inspection report indicates if SSOA Staff needs to follow up. All inspections
that necessitate a follow-up will be logged in the Field work tracker.

●

The SSOA Staff’s name, job title, and email address who performed the
inspection will be noted in the inspection report and the automatically generated
email.

●

All SSOA Staff from the SSOA unit of the Rail & Transit Safety Section of the
Colorado PUC will issue the inspection report.

SAFETY CONCERNS
●

If an emergency occurs during an inspection, SSOA Staff is required to call 9-1-1
in any situation that requires immediate assistance from police, firefighters, or
paramedics for three reasons: 1) to stop a crime; 2) to report a fire; or 3) to save a
life. Once 9-1-1 is called for any of the above three reasons, if necessary, SSOA
Staff are required to contact the RTA’s Control Center to report any emergencies
and/or safety concerns discovered during an inspection. SSOA Staff will
immediately stop the inspection until the safety concern is addressed, and it is safe
to continue, or if it is not safe to continue the inspection, the inspection will be
immediately stopped and rescheduled. A formal report will be sent to the RTA
with details of the event and/or safety concerns, including any video or photos
that may be available at the time once the inspection is stopped. If the inspection
requires a follow-up, the report will be marked for a follow-up with the RTA.
The RTA and SSOA Staff will meet once a month to discuss inspections that were
marked for a follow-up. The RTA and SSOA Staff will meet sooner if the
situation needs immediate follow-up.

●

When an immediate safety concern is discovered during a field inspection, the
inspection report will be noted as High Priority (Serious issue requiring
immediate action, i.e. Risks and hazards with a High or Serious ranking code of
1A, 2A, 1B, 1C, 2C, 3A, or 3B). Inspection Reports noted as High Priority will
indicate a follow-up by the SSOA Staff. High-Priority Inspection Reports will

Attachment: PTASP_Exhibits_2026 (5203 : 2026 Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP))

4.0

All inspections entered in the Field Work form are identified as Risk-Based
Inspections.

47

●

During a field inspection, the inspection report will be noted as Low Priority
(Risks and hazards with a Medium or Moderate ranking code of 4A, 5A, 4B, 5B,
3C, 4C, 1D, 2D, 3D, 3D, 1E, or 2E), the inspection report will automatically be
sent to the SSOA Staff, Safety Team, and Safety Supervisors.

●

Other safety concerns will be noted as For Information Only (Risks and hazards
with a Low-ranking code of 5C, 4D, 5D, 3E, 4E, or 5E) and the inspection report
will automatically be sent to the SSOA Staff, Safety Team, and Safety
Supervisors

Packet Pg. 635

4.A.b

Event Verification

SSOA Staff will assess whether the RTA is leveraging data and information collected through
the activity to determine probable cause to support the identification of hazards and events. The
event investigation review process includes, but is not limited to, reviewing safety event
investigations, identification of causal and contributing factors through reports from the RTA’s
high potential investigations, documentation review, areas with similar characteristics will be
inspected, post event inspections from previous event inspections are leveraged and findings
from audits and inspections performed by SSOA Staff. SSOA Staff will review all event
investigation documentation and request additional documentation as needed. Information is
reviewed continually as events occur. SSOA Staff will use the results of its ongoing review of
event investigation documentation to identify any trends in non-compliance or safety concerns.
The SSOA Program Manager will track all events, CAPs, field inspections, hazards, defects, and
remedial actions in a tracking log, once action items are closed The SSOA Staff will verify 6
months and 12 months after action items have been closed that action items are still being
performed and effective. The SSOA Program Manager will track inspection data, CAP closures,
defects, and events through a spreadsheet. Follow-ups will be prioritized based on risk ranking.
The SSOA Program Manager will schedule inspections, documentation review, or additional
meetings with the RTA based on the risk ranking assigned to the findings.

PROCEDURE

The procedure to be used by SSOA Staff when driving the light rail alignment is as follows:

4.0

●

Choose an alignment to be inspected

●

Document on PUC shared Rail calendar day, time, and alignment of inspection

●

Open the PUC Rail-Transit Field Work form

●

Fill out the form with observations

●

The form entry will automatically populate a report that will be emailed to the
SSOA Staff and RTA.

●

All SSOA Staff from the SSOA unit of the Rail & Transit Safety Section of the
Colorado PUC will issue the inspection report.

●

All form entries will be collected on a spreadsheet found in Google Drive

PERFORMING ALIGNMENT CHECKS

Items to be observed and documented
●

While being parked safely with a rail vehicle that has proper safety gear, test the
timing of gate arms at grade crossings.

●

While being parked safely with a rail vehicle that has proper safety gear, listen for
proper horn use through grade crossings. Proper horn use is 2 long horn blasts, 1
short horn blast, ending with one more 1 long horn blast.

●

Visually inspect that the TPS and Relay houses are locked if MOW workers are
not present in locations that are accessible to the public

●

Watch that trains are properly using the wig-wag lights in the downtown
alignment

●

When two SSOA Staff are available, drive alignment and visually look at bridges
and flyovers

PROCEDURE FOR PERFORMING FIELD OBSERVATION DRIVING RAIL ALIGNMENT INSPECTIONS

51
Packet Pg. 637

4.A.b

●

SAFETY CONCERNS

If an emergency occurs during an inspection, SSOA Staff are required to call 9-1-1 in any
situation that requires immediate assistance from police, firefighters, or paramedics for three
reasons: 1) to stop a crime; 2) to report a fire; or 3) to save a life. Once 9-1-1 is called for any of
the above three reasons, if necessary, SSOA Staff are required to contact the RTA’s Control
Center to report any emergencies and/or safety concerns discovered during an inspection. SSOA
Staff will immediately stop the inspection until the safety concern is addressed, and it is safe to
continue, or if it is not safe to continue the inspection, the inspection will be immediately stopped
and rescheduled. A formal report will be sent to the RTA with details of the event and/or safety
concerns, including any video or photos that may be available at the time once the inspection is
stopped. If the inspection requires a follow-up, the report will be marked for a follow-up with
the RTA. The RTA and SSOA Staff will meet once a month to discuss inspections that were
marked for a follow-up. The RTA and SSOA Staff will meet sooner if the situation needs
immediate follow-up.

Attachment: PTASP_Exhibits_2026 (5203 : 2026 Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP))

5.0

While safely parked with a rail vehicle that has proper safety gear, use a radar
detector that is in a rail vehicle to do speed checks on trains.

PROCEDURE FOR PERFORMING FIELD OBSERVATION SPECIAL PROJECTS

65
Packet Pg. 651

4.A.b

SAFETY CONCERNS

If an emergency occurs during an inspection, SSOA Staff are required to call 9-1-1 in any
situation that requires immediate assistance from police, firefighters, or paramedics for three
reasons: 1) to stop a crime; 2) to report a fire; or 3) to save a life. Once 9-1-1 is called for any of
the above three reasons, if necessary, SSOA Staff are required to contact the RTA’s Control
Center to report any emergencies and/or safety concerns discovered during an inspection. SSOA
Staff will immediately stop the inspection until the safety concern is addressed, and it is safe to
continue, or if it is not safe to continue the inspection, the inspection will be immediately stopped
and rescheduled. A formal report will be sent to the RTA with details of the event and/or safety
concerns, including any video or photos that may be available at the time once the inspection is
stopped. If the inspection requires a follow-up, the report will be marked for a follow-up with
the RTA. The RTA and SSOA Staff will meet once a month to discuss inspections that were
marked for a follow-up. The RTA and SSOA Staff will meet sooner if the situation needs
immediate follow-up.

PROCEDURE FOR SAFETY OVERSIGHT OF DESIGN,
CONSTRUCTION, OPERATION, AND MAINTENANCE OF
RAIL FIXED GUIDEWAY SYSTEMS
1.0

SCOPE

This procedure describes the activities of SSOA Staff for safety oversight of the design,
construction, operation, and maintenance of rail fixed guideway systems.
2.0

PURPOSE

The purpose of this procedure is to provide a general guideline to be used by SSOA Staff when
performing safety oversight of transit agencies during design, construction, operation, and
maintenance.
3.0

PROCEDURE

The activities of SSOA Staff for safety oversight during design, construction, operation, and
maintenance of a rail fixed guideway system may include, but are not limited to, the following:
3.1

DESIGN
•
•
•
•
•
•
•
•
•
•
•
•
•
•
•
•

Reviewing drawings of the system route and positioning of safety signaling
equipment
Reviewing equipment technical specifications
Reviewing drawings for compliance with the RTA design codes and standards,
including the relevant and most recent edition standards and guidelines of various
Federal, State, and local jurisdictions
Specific codes and standards include, but are not limited to, the following:
Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)
ADA Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG) for Buildings and Facilities
ADAAG for Transportation Vehicles
Colorado Department of Transportation (CDOT) - Standard Specifications for
Road and Bridge Construction
CDOT - Standard Plans (M&S Standards)
CDOT - Highway Design Manual
CDOT - Drainage Design Manual
Standard design and construction specifications of the roadway authority
FHWA - Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways
(MUTCD)
RTA’s Light Rail Design Criteria
RTA’s Standard Plans for Bus & Light Rail Transit Facilities
2009 International Building Code

E.21 2026 PTASP Approval

569

Packet Pg. 662

4.A.b

■

We mak liv s better
through connections.

Pursuant to 49 CFR Part 673, the Federal Transit Administration (FTA) requires all recipients and
subrecipients of Urbanized Area Formula Grant Program funds under 49 U.S.C. §5307, and each
operator of a rail transit system subject to a State Safety Oversight Program, to develop, implement,
and annually review a Public Transportation Agency Safety Plan (PTASP).
The 2026 PTASP updates include:
•

Safety Performance Trends - Three-year rolling average and targets tracked and reported
to the National Transit Database (NTD)

•

Accident and Hazard Reporting - Updated criteria for accidents and hazards under
Colorado Public Utilities Commission program standards to ensure clear and consistent
reporting

•

Employee and Contractor Safety - Strengthening protections to reduce risks and ensure
safety

Per the 2021 Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL) and 49 CFR 673, the agency's safety committee is
required to review and approve the PTASP annually. The Joint Labor-Management Safety Committee
(JLMSC) is composed of six representatives from RTD management and six from the Amalgamated
Transit Union Local 1001 (ATU 1001), as defined by the JLMSC Charter.
This memorandum confirms that the JLMSC formally approved the 2026 PTASP on October 23, 2025.
Co-Chair, RTD

Co-Chair, ATU Local 1001

Timothy Tyran, Chief Safety Officer

Julian Gutierrez, Vice President
